questions.question: In the storage hierarchy from registers to tapes, what is the primary trade-off that governs the design of each level?
options: Speed vs. capacity
Volatility vs. durability
Cost vs. reliability
Power consumption vs. heat generation
questions.explanation: The fundamental trade-off in storage hierarchy is speed vs. capacity - faster storage (like registers) has very limited capacity, while slower storage (like tapes) can hold much more data.

questions.question: A database application needs to frequently access a small working set of records while maintaining a large archive of historical data. Based on storage hierarchy principles, what would be the most appropriate strategy?
options: Store everything in main memory for consistent performance
Keep working set in cache/memory and archive on slower storage
Use only solid-state drives to balance speed and capacity
Distribute all data equally across all storage levels
questions.explanation: This follows the principle of locality - frequently accessed data should be kept in faster storage levels, while less frequently accessed data can reside in slower, higher-capacity storage.

questions.question: Why do CPU registers sit at the top of the storage hierarchy rather than having all storage at that speed level?
options: Registers are unreliable and lose data easily
The physical constraints and cost make it impractical to have large amounts of register-speed storage
Registers can only store integers, not other data types
Operating systems cannot manage large numbers of registers
questions.explanation: Register-speed storage requires expensive, power-hungry circuits located very close to the CPU. Physical and economic constraints limit how much storage can operate at this speed.

questions.question: In a virtual memory system, what storage hierarchy principle is being applied when pages are moved between RAM and disk?
options: Static partitioning based on file type
Temporal locality - recently accessed pages stay in faster storage
Random distribution to balance load
Alphabetical ordering of data
questions.explanation: Virtual memory systems use temporal locality principles, keeping recently accessed pages in RAM (faster storage) and moving less recently used pages to disk (slower storage).

questions.question: A system architect is designing storage for a real-time video processing application that must guarantee response times. Which characteristic of the storage hierarchy is most critical to consider?
options: The total capacity of the slowest storage level
The access time predictability at each level
The power consumption of storage devices
The alphabetical organization of stored data
questions.explanation: For real-time applications, predictable access times are crucial. The architect must understand not just average speeds but worst-case access times at each storage level to guarantee response times.
